message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Microscopic Origin of the Quantum Mpemba Effect in Integrable Systems
Paper Abstract: The highly complicated nature of far from equilibrium systems can lead to a complete breakdown of the physical intuition developed in equilibrium. A famous example of this is the Mpemba effect, which states that nonequilibrium states may relax faster when they are further from equilibrium or, put another way, hot water can freeze faster than warm water. Despite possessing a storied history, the precise criteria and mechanisms underpinning this phenomenon are still not known. Here, we study a quantum version of the Mpemba effect that takes place in closed many-body systems with a U(1) conserved charge: in certain cases a more asymmetric initial configuration relaxes and restores the symmetry faster than a more symmetric one. In contrast to the classical case, we establish the criteria for this to occur in arbitrary integrable quantum systems using the recently introduced entanglement asymmetry. We describe the quantum Mpemba effect in such systems and relate the properties of the initial state, specifically its charge fluctuations, to the criteria for its occurrence. These criteria are expounded using exact analytic and numerical techniques in several examples, a free fermion model, the Rule 54 cellular automaton, and the Lieb-Liniger model.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Lieb-Liniger model:

## Overview

The Lieb–Liniger model describes a gas of particles moving in one dimension and satisfying Bose–Einstein statistics, specifically a one dimensional Bose gas with Dirac delta interactions.(no content)It is named after Elliott H. Lieb and Werner Liniger who introduced the model in 1963.

## Historical Context and Development

The model was developed to compare and test Nikolay Bogolyubov's theory of a weakly interacting Bose gas.(no content)Elliott H. Lieb and Werner Liniger provided the exact solution of the 1d δ-function interacting Bose gas (now known as the Lieb-Liniger model).(no content)In 1969, C. N. Yang and C. P. Yang obtained the thermodynamics of the Lieb-Liniger model, providing the basis of the thermodynamic Bethe ansatz (TBA).

## Mathematical Properties

When the number of particles is finite, a quantum field theory describing bosonic point particles with delta-function interactions is equivalent to the Lieb–Liniger model.(no content)In the limit of infinite strength repulsion, the Lieb–Liniger model becomes the Tonks–Girardeau gas (also called the hard-core Bose gas, or impenetrable Bose gas).

Links: [{"title":"Fermion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermion"},{"title":"Boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boson"},{"title":"Numerical sign problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_sign_problem"},{"title":"Bosonization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosonization"},{"title":"Anyon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anyon"},{"title":"Parity (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_(physics)"},{"title":"List of particles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_particles"},{"title":"Weyl equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weyl_equation"},{"title":"Semi-Dirac fermion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-Dirac_fermion"},{"title":"Chirality (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chirality_(physics)"}]

Here's information about fermion physics from the search results:

## What are Fermions?

In particle physics, a fermion is a subatomic particle that follows Fermi–Dirac statistics.(no content)Fermions have a half-integer spin (spin ⁠1/2⁠, spin · ⁠3/2⁠, etc.) and obey the Pauli exclusion principle.

## Key Characteristics

As a consequence of the Pauli exclusion principle, only one fermion can occupy a particular quantum state at a given time.(no content)Fermions are usually associated with matter, whereas bosons are generally force carrier particles.

## Elementary Fermions

The Standard Model recognizes two types of elementary fermions: quarks and leptons. There are six quarks (up, down, strange, charm, bottom and top), and six leptons (electron, electron neutrino, muon, muon neutrino, tau and tau neutrino), along with the corresponding antiparticle of each of these.

## Types of Fermions

Mathematically, there are many varieties of fermions, with the three most common types being: Majorana fermions (each its own antiparticle). Most Standard Model fermions are believed to be Dirac fermions, although it is unknown at this time whether the neutrinos are Dirac or Majorana fermions (or both).

## Special Behavior

At low temperatures, fermions show superfluidity for uncharged particles and superconductivity for charged particles.

Web search results for query: "integrable systems"

Links: [{"title":"Integrable system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrable_system"},{"title":"Category:Integrable systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Integrable_systems"},{"title":"Tau function (integrable systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tau_function_(integrable_systems)"},{"title":"Garnier integrable system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garnier_integrable_system"},{"title":"List of integrable models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_integrable_models"},{"title":"Integrability conditions for differential systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrability_conditions_for_differential_systems"},{"title":"Hitchin system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hitchin_system"},{"title":"Superintegrable Hamiltonian system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superintegrable_Hamiltonian_system"},{"title":"Integrable algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrable_algorithm"},{"title":"Gelfand–Zeitlin integrable system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gelfand–Zeitlin_integrable_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of integrable systems:

## Definition

An integrable system is a dynamical system with sufficiently many conserved quantities, or first integrals, that its motion is confined to a submanifold of much smaller dimensionality than that of its phase space.

## Key Characteristics

Three features often characterize integrable systems: the existence of a maximal set of conserved quantities, the existence of algebraic invariants based in algebraic geometry, and the explicit determination of solutions in an explicit functional form.(no content)Integrable systems are qualitatively very different from generic dynamical systems, which are more typically chaotic systems that have no conserved quantities and are asymptotically intractable.

## Examples

Many systems studied in physics are completely integrable, including multi-dimensional harmonic oscillators, planetary motion about one or two fixed centers, the motion of a rigid body about its center of mass (the Euler top), and the motion of an axially symmetric rigid body about a point in its axis of symmetry (the Lagrange top).(no content)In the late 1960s, it was realized that there are completely integrable systems in physics having an infinite number of degrees of freedom, such as some models of shallow water waves (Korteweg–de Vries equation), the Kerr effect in optical fibres, and certain integrable many-body systems like the Toda lattice.

## Applications

There are relatively few models in physics which have non-linear terms or couplings and can still be solved exactly, without resorting to perturbation theory, making such models celebrated.

Links: [{"title":"Entropy of entanglement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_of_entanglement"},{"title":"Quantum entanglement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_entanglement"},{"title":"Von Neumann entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Neumann_entropy"},{"title":"Quantum relative entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_relative_entropy"},{"title":"Topological entropy in physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_entropy_in_physics"},{"title":"Joint quantum entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_quantum_entropy"},{"title":"Entanglement distillation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entanglement_distillation"},{"title":"Separable state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separable_state"},{"title":"Talk:Quantum entanglement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantum_entanglement"},{"title":"Negativity (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_negativity"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about entanglement entropy in quantum mechanics:

## Definition and Core Concept

The entropy of entanglement (or entanglement entropy) is a measure of the degree of quantum entanglement between two subsystems constituting a two-part composite quantum system. More specifically, the entropy of entanglement is the Von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix for any of the subsystems.

## How It Works

If it is non-zero, it indicates the two subsystems are entangled. For pure bipartite states, the von Neumann entropy of reduced states is the unique measure of entanglement in the sense that it is the only function on the family of states that satisfies certain axioms required of an entanglement measure.

## Key Properties

Links: [{"title":"Cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Elementary cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elementary_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Cyclic cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclic_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Codd's cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Codd's_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Stochastic cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Quantum cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Block cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Second-order cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-order_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Oscillator (cellular automaton) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oscillator_(cellular_automaton)"},{"title":"Category:Cellular automaton patterns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cellular_automaton_patterns"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about cellular automata:

## Overview

A cellular automaton (CA) is a discrete model of computation studied in automata theory.(no content)A cellular automaton consists of a regular grid of cells, each in one of a finite number of states, and a new generation is created according to some fixed rule that determines the new state of each cell in terms of the current state of the cell and the states of the cells in its neighborhood.

## History

The concept was originally conceived in the 1940s by Stanislaw Ulam and John von Neumann while they were contemporaries at Los Alamos National Laboratory.(no content)While studied by some throughout the 1950s and 1960s, it was not until the 1970s and Conway's Game of Life, a two-dimensional cellular automaton, that interest in the subject expanded beyond academia.

## How They Work

The rule for updating the state of cells is typically the same for each cell and does not change over time, and is applied to the whole grid simultaneously.(no content)The two most common types of neighborhoods are the von Neumann neighborhood, which consists of the four orthogonally adjacent cells, and the Moore neighborhood, which includes the von Neumann neighborhood as well as the four diagonally adjacent cells.

## Applications

Cellular automata have found application in various areas, including physics, theoretical biology and microstructure modeling.

## Types of Cellular Automata

There are several variants, including:
- Elementary cellular automaton: a one-dimensional cellular automaton where there are two possible states and the rule depends only on the current state of the cell and its two immediate neighbors.
- Stochastic (or probabilistic) cellular automata, where the rules are probabilistic rather than deterministic, meaning a cell's next state is determined by chance according to a set of probabilities.
- Second-order cellular automaton: a type of reversible cellular automaton where the state of a cell depends not only on its neighborhood at time t − 1, but also on its state at time t − 2.

Links: [{"title":"Mpemba effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mpemba_effect"},{"title":"Erasto B. Mpemba - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erasto_B._Mpemba"},{"title":"Talk:Mpemba effect/Archives/ 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Mpemba_effect/Archives/_1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Talk:Mpemba effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Mpemba_effect"},{"title":"Mpemba - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mpemba"},{"title":"Mpemba (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mpemba_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Mfinda - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mfinda"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Science/2012 February 23 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Science/2012_February_23"},{"title":"Chido Cleopatra Mpemba - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chido_Cleopatra_Mpemba"},{"title":"Leidenfrost effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leidenfrost_effect"}]

## The Mpemba Effect

The Mpemba effect is the observation that hot liquids or colloids (such as ice cream) can freeze more quickly than colder ones, for similar volumes and surrounding conditions. However, physicists remain divided on the effect's reproducibility, precise definition, and underlying mechanisms.

### Discovery and History

The effect is named after Tanzanian student Erasto Mpemba, who described it in 1963 in Form 3 of Magamba Secondary School, Tanganyika; when freezing a hot ice cream mixture in a cookery class, he noticed that it froze before a cold mixture.(no content)When Osborne experimented on the issue back at his workplace, he confirmed Mpemba's finding. They later published the results together in 1969, while Mpemba was studying at the College of African Wildlife Management.

### Scientific Investigation

Mpemba and Osborne described placing 70 ml samples of water in 100 ml beakers in the icebox of a domestic refrigerator on a sheet of polystyrene foam. They showed the time for freezing to start was longest with an initial temperature of 25 °C (77 °F) and that it was much less at around 90 °C (194 °F).(no content)Modern studies using freezers with well-understood properties have observed the Mpemba effect where water supercools before freezing. Water that starts out cooler tends to reach a lower supercooled temperature before freezing.(no content)In 2021, John Bechhoefer described a way to reliably reproduce the effect. In 2024, Argelia Ortega, et al. studied the freezing of small (1-20mL) drops in a Peltier cell with a thermographic camera, and found that hot drops consistently froze faster than cold ones, with a more pronounced difference for larger drops.

## The Mpemba Effect

The Mpemba effect is the observation that hot liquids or colloids (such as ice cream) can freeze more quickly than colder ones, for similar volumes and surrounding conditions. However, physicists remain divided on the effect's reproducibility, precise definition, and underlying mechanisms.

### Discovery and History

The effect is named after Tanzanian student Erasto Mpemba, who described it in 1963 in Form 3 of Magamba Secondary School, Tanganyika; when freezing a hot ice cream mixture in a cookery class, he noticed that it froze before a cold mixture.(no content)When Osborne experimented on the issue back at his workplace, he confirmed Mpemba's finding. They later published the results together in 1969, while Mpemba was studying at the College of African Wildlife Management.

### Scientific Investigation

Mpemba and Osborne described placing 70 ml samples of water in 100 ml beakers in the icebox of a domestic refrigerator on a sheet of polystyrene foam. They showed the time for freezing to start was longest with an initial temperature of 25 °C (77 °F) and that it was much less at around 90 °C (194 °F).(no content)Modern studies using freezers with well-understood properties have observed the Mpemba effect where water supercools before freezing. Water that starts out cooler tends to reach a lower supercooled temperature before freezing.(no content)In 2021, John Bechhoefer described a way to reliably reproduce the effect. In 2024, Argelia Ortega, et al. studied the freezing of small (1-20mL) drops in a Peltier cell with a thermographic camera, and found that hot drops consistently froze faster than cold ones, with a more pronounced difference for larger drops.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**

The paper on "Microscopic Origin of the Quantum Mpemba Effect in Integrable Systems" has been successfully analyzed and classified as a **contribution** paper. 

**Identified Triples (7 total):**

1. **Mpemba effect** (concept) - The classical phenomenon the paper extends to quantum systems
2. **Integrable system** (concept) - The theoretical framework used for analysis
3. **Entropy of entanglement** (concept) - Related to the entanglement asymmetry used to establish criteria
4. **Cellular automaton** (artifact) - Rule 54 used as an example system
5. **Fermion** (concept) - Free fermion models used for analysis
6. **Lieb-Liniger model** (artifact) - 1D Bose gas example system
7. **Quantum Mpemba effect** (concept - **proposes**) - The novel contribution establishing microscopic origins and criteria

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script has passed with no errors.

Sources:
- [Mpemba effect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mpemba_effect)
- [Integrable system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrable_system)
- [Cellular automaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton)
- [Fermion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermion)
- [Entropy of entanglement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_of_entanglement)
- [Lieb-Liniger model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lieb%E2%80%93Liniger_model)
